rn-core-01.prompt: Which component is the most fundamental building block for UI, acting as a container that supports layout with Flexbox?
rn-core-01.explanation: The <View> component maps directly to the native equivalent (UIView on iOS, android.view on Android) and is used for layout and styling.
rn-core-01.interviewTip: Think of <View> as the <div> of React Native.

rn-core-02.prompt: What will happen if you try to render raw text outside of a <Text> component?
rn-core-02.explanation: Unlike the web where text can exist inside a <div>, React Native requires all text to be explicitly wrapped in a <Text> component.
rn-core-02.interviewTip: This is a very common beginner mistake when transitioning from Web to Mobile.
options: It renders correctly as a child of the View.
It will throw an error: 'Text strings must be rendered within a <Text> component'.
It renders but cannot be styled.
React Native automatically wraps it in a <Text> tag.

rn-core-03.prompt: How do you display a remote image from a URL in React Native?
rn-core-03.explanation: Remote images require an object with a 'uri' property. Local images use the 'require' function.
rn-core-03.interviewTip: Remember that remote images in React Native do not have an automatic size; you MUST specify width and height in the styles or they won't show up.

rn-core-04.prompt: What is the primary purpose of the 'StyleSheet.create' method?
rn-core-04.explanation: StyleSheet.create sends the style object through the bridge only once, rather than recreating it on every render, which is more efficient.
rn-core-04.interviewTip: It also provides validation, throwing errors if you use invalid CSS properties that React Native doesn't support.
options: To allow the use of CSS files (.css) in React Native.
To provide a centralized and potentially more performant way to define styles outside the render loop.
To automatically convert pixels to percentages.
To encrypt the styles for security.

rn-core-05.prompt: Which component should you use if you need a container that allows the user to swipe through content that is larger than the screen?
rn-core-05.explanation: A <View> has no scrolling capabilities. For basic scrolling of a small amount of content, <ScrollView> is the correct choice.
rn-core-05.interviewTip: For large lists of data, <ScrollView> is inefficient because it renders all children at once. Use <FlatList> instead for performance.

rn-core-06.prompt: Which of the following properties are valid for the <Text> component in React Native?
rn-core-06.explanation: The <Text> component is surprisingly powerful, supporting truncation, native touch events, and copy-paste selection.
rn-core-06.interviewTip: Nested <Text> components inherit styles from their parents, which is different from how <View> inheritance works.
options: onPress (to handle clicks directly on text)
selectable (to allow the user to copy-paste)

rn-core-07.prompt: How do you handle local assets (like a logo) in an <Image> component?
rn-core-07.explanation: The 'require' syntax allows the packager to bundle the image metadata (width, height, path) during build time.
rn-core-07.interviewTip: Unlike remote images, local images usually don't need explicit width/height to appear, though it's still good practice to set them.
options: This is the correct way for local assets.
Local assets must also use the { uri: ... } syntax.
You must import the image as a default export first.
React Native only supports remote images.

rn-core-08.prompt: What is the difference between <View> and <SafeAreaView>?
rn-core-08.explanation: SafeAreaView is essential for iOS devices with notches to ensure content isn't hidden behind system UI elements.
rn-core-08.interviewTip: In modern development, many developers use the 'react-native-safe-area-context' library for even better control over safe areas.
options: <SafeAreaView> automatically adds padding to avoid 'notches', status bars, and home indicators on modern devices.
<View> is only for web, <SafeAreaView> is for mobile.

rn-core-09.prompt: What is the result of applying 'flexDirection' to a <View> in React Native?
rn-core-09.explanation: In standard Web CSS, the default is 'row'. In React Native, the default is 'column' to better suit vertical mobile screens.
rn-core-09.interviewTip: This is one of the most frequent 'gotchas' for web developers moving to React Native.
options: It has no default; it must be specified.

rn-core-10.prompt: Which component is used to collect text input from the user?
rn-core-10.explanation: TextInput is the core component for keyboard input. It supports various keyboard types (numeric, email) and secure text entry for passwords.
rn-core-10.interviewTip: Always handle the 'onChangeText' prop (which gives the string directly) rather than 'onChange' (which gives an event object).

rn-core-11.prompt: How do you apply multiple style objects to a single component?
rn-core-11.explanation: React Native's 'style' prop accepts an array of objects. The last object in the array takes precedence (overwrites previous ones).
rn-core-11.interviewTip: This is perfect for conditional styling: style={[styles.box, isActive && styles.activeBox]}.

rn-core-12.prompt: What is the purpose of the <ActivityIndicator /> component?
rn-core-12.explanation: It's a built-in component that displays a native loading spinner (UIActivityIndicator on iOS, ProgressBar on Android).
rn-core-12.interviewTip: You can customize its size ('small' or 'large') and color.
options: To display a circular loading spinner.
To track user activity for analytics.

rn-core-13.prompt: Which of these are valid 'resizeMode' values for an <Image> component?
rn-core-13.explanation: resizeMode determines how the image should be scaled when the frame doesn't match the image aspect ratio.
rn-core-13.interviewTip: 'cover' is the default and usually what you want for full-bleed backgrounds.

rn-core-14.prompt: Why is it important to use 'key' in a list of components rendered inside a ScrollView?
rn-core-14.explanation: Just like React on the Web, the reconciliation algorithm uses keys to track the identity of elements in an array.
rn-core-14.interviewTip: Using the array index as a key is generally discouraged if the order of items can change.
options: To help React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed for efficient re-rendering.
Keys are not needed in ScrollView, only in FlatList.

rn-core-15.prompt: What does the 'contentContainerStyle' prop do on a <ScrollView>?
rn-core-15.explanation: If you apply padding to a ScrollView's 'style' prop, the content will be cut off. You must use 'contentContainerStyle' to add padding to the scrollable area itself.
rn-core-15.interviewTip: This is the most common way to add 'breathing room' at the bottom of a scrollable list.
options: It styles the outer wrapper of the scroll view.
It styles the inner component that wraps all the children (used for padding/alignment).
It changes the color of the scroll bar.
It is used for the background color only.

rn-core-16.prompt: What will the following code render on the screen?
rn-core-16.explanation: By default, Views have 'alignItems: stretch', so it will take up the full width of its parent and act as a 1-pixel high line.
rn-core-16.interviewTip: This is a common way to create custom border-like separators between list items.
options: Nothing, because it has no width.
